Another article about California law enforcement agencies making illegal Flock searches for ICE and CBP. We found thousands of such searches via public records requests.

We obtained Flock Network Audit logs via a public records request showing searches that other police agencies have made on the Santa Cruz, CA Police Department's Flock ALPR camera network. Thousands were illegal. We sent the data to Have I Been Flocked - an excellent resource that we use daily.

We tipped this reporter to the fact that Flock's Private Investigator license in Texas had expired. This puts criminal prosecutions at risk across Texas: ""Cain, an attorney, told The Texan that data collected by Flock under an expired state license is not admissible in court.""

Our research showed that after Flock turned off National Lookup in California, ICE and CBP were asking California police officers to search Flock for plate numbers and many officers did so, in violation of two California laws and their own department's policy. Get the Flock out of California!

This was aggravated stalking and must have been horrible for the targeted persons. The ex-chief stalked three individuals for over eight months and made hundreds of searches of Flock camera data for the victims' plate numbers. Most of his searches where nationwide, querying over 90,000 cameras.

Our research showed that 63 California police agencies violated State law by sharing Flock data out-of-state (SB 34) and by sharing data for immigration enforcement purposes (SB 54). We sent each of them a data breach advisory. Flock's business model is not compatible with California law.
